div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE PANAMA CANAL. WORK ON WRONG LINES. MONEY SPENT WASTED
div.p: Garette's Special! Service
London, Tuesday.

The "Daily Telegraph's' correspondent at Washington states that the cost of the Panama Canal has been greatly onder estimated and will probably necessitate doubling the present & timate of £2* 000,000. The work has been done on wrong lines and the great portion of the money spent has been wasted. Conse quently many years muat elapse before the completion of the Canal.

"Miasir'' ot the same line is assisting in towing off the "Negnileb " She lies on a sandy bottom and it is not expected that she is damaged.

As we go 'to press we learn that the second offeer of the "Missir' died last night Particulars are not yet to band, but death is believed to be due to an aceitent ineurred during the efforts to tow off the "Neguileh."

div.head: OBITUARY. MISS F. COLLINS
div.p: 'he sad news of the death of Mias F. Collins at Luxor has called forth expressions of sincerest feeling not only in Luxor but in Cairo where she was so well known in various circles. It ia some fifteen years ago that the Misses Collina first made acquaintance with Egypt, and since then Miss D.C 8. Collins bas been constantly asenciated with the country in her capacity as Deaconess Her two sisters have been in the habit of dividing their winters between the Hotel d Angleterre, Cairo, and the Loxor Hotel, Luxor, and each year bas found them more beloved and respected by all of those, rich and poor, Europeau and native with whom they came in touch. Though English by birth, they had lived the best part of their lives in Edin burgh acd were staunch adherents to the Scottish church. It is only ome fortnight or so ago that they bade farewell to their friends | in Cairo and followed by the good wishes of all } they wernt back to their old yuarlers in Luxor Mise F. Colline who was the youngest and most active of the sisters, has always assisted in the services at the church by presiding over the harmonium, and it waa while in her seat dur ng service last Sunday that she suddenly and unexpected |y eX} red The aac news did not become generally known in Cairo til! yesterday, when expressions of universal regret were heard on all sides, and especially from those who had had the pleasure of serving the dece-sed lady duriug the many years shebhad passed among them

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION. — REPORTED REDUCTION,
div.p: London, Tuesday.

aa "Standard" states that it is onderstocd that during 1908-9 the Egyptian garrison wil be reduced from 5,500 to 4,000. The sixth Dragoons will be sent to India and the third Coldstream Guards on withdrawal from Cairo will not be relieved by another battalion.
[We are officially authorised- to contradict the statement of the "Standard," which was also reported by Reuter yesterday. Ep. E.G)

div.head: DR- RUTHERFORD'S VISIT.
div.p: On Sunday Dr. Ratherford weot to Alexandria where he was shown over some Govern- ment schools, likewise that of the Orwa el Woska Society and the Victoria College. He was immensely struck with the magnificent quays with which Alexandria is provided He returned to Cairo yesterday, Yesterday be attended the Khedivial reception and was received in audience by his Highness opon the introduction of Mr. Ronald W. Graham, Councillor of the British Embassy. Besides the banquet which is to be given in bis honour at the Semiramis Hotel on Saterday by the Sonstitational Reform Leagee, he bas consent. ed to attend a meeting at the central offices of that organisation on Friday to receive an atidress, Business first, pleasure afterwards seems to be the League's motto.

div.head: THE IMPERIAL PIERROTS.
div.p: The Imperial Pierrots bmve been so far sve- cesstul in their efforts to please Thet they have booked engagements for nearly every evening throughout the remaining weeks of the season, and are appearing in Helowan as wellas io Cairo. They had a bumper audience at Shepheard's last week, when nearly each item in the programme received an encore, and though their performance at the Con- tinental was not so numerously attended it was the means of bringing them various other engagements. Mr. Harry Sellars, the manager, has been singularly fortanate in obtaining the services of two members of the well-known Oarl Rosa Company. Both Mr. S. Harland, the tenor, and Mr. Thomas, the baritone, possess most excellent voices, and their solos are always in request. made a very distinct impression with his first song "My Dream", and his rendering later on in the programme of "I'll sing thee songs of Araby' was far and away the most enjoyable item of the evening. The choruses and glees given by the quartette both with and withont accompaniment were sung with considerable crispoess and in excellent style. The drawing: room at the Continental is not the easiest place in which to give such an entertainment, and the piano ased on Priday was not iv the best of condition, but we look forward with interest to our next opportunity of listening to the performance of the Imperial Pierrots

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS. DENISHWAI.
div.p: The manner in which the news of the release of the Denishwai prisoners has been received is worthy of note. The absence of anything like excitement, demonstration or unrest on the part of the populace is especially gratifying and redounds very much to their credit. This shows that the people of Egypt are making progress in the appreciation of their own dignity and a sense of becoming self-respect. Exceptions prove the rale. Unfortanetely we must call attention to the ravings and rantings and hysterical exeltation of the controlled by Mustapha Pasha Kamel. Nothing of course could have been in worse taste or more distant from the troth than his assertion of having in the smallest degree contributed to the exercise of clemency by the Khedive. To take up soch a standpoint is absolute effrontery. The Pasha clearly thinks that he can turn the occasion to his own adVantage and so we meet with paragraphs such as these in his newepapers-

"The generous decision of the National Party at the meeting of the General Assembly to erect a kuttab at Denishwai as a fitting memorial of the tragedy has been received with delight io all parts of Egypt."

"Letters of congratulation are daily reaching Our Director thanking him in his quality of Leader for the Party for the enlightened direc tion that has been given to the national commemoration of Denishwai."
Or again :-—
"The snbseriptions for the Denishwai which are being collected by "Al- Lewa" have realised LE 183 and 660 milliémes."'
Evidently these items of news were inspired to throw dust in the eyes of the ignorant, bot happily they appear to have been received with stony apathy.

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY
div.p: The scheme for a National University has now been before the public tor a considerable time but has hitherto only received miserably inadequate subscriptions. Whether this cold reception is doe to indifference or to defects in the scheme as it presents itself to the minds of the Egyptians, we are anable to judge However, geserous help is now at hand of a very substantial character which ought to set the enterprise going on thoroughly business lines. The Khedive has consented to an endow. ment of LE 5,00) a year to be taken from the Wakfs Adininistration. This new departore should show the Egyptians that the project has received the Khedivial approbation and is a satisfactory proof ef the enlightened interest which his Highness manifests in the ed2cation of his subjeota.

div.head: EGYPT'S WINTER
div.p: Our Cairo Corresponiient writes

January is nearly half over and there is still no sign of winter in Egypt. There was a slight mist in Cairo until about nine o'clock on Sun- day morning certainly, but by ten o'clock the sun had dispelled the last suspicion of this, and the streets were flooded with sun of an almost equal strength to that of summer. Are we to get any winter at all this season! Opinions upon this point are varied in the extreme. On the one hand it is predicted that the coming Febroary will be one of record cold, and on the other it said that the first balf of January over, we shal] have no reason to fear the advent of cold weather during the present season. It is certainly a most unusual experience for the residents.of Cairo to pass this month in a state of perspiration in the day time and one of warm comfort at night. This time last year people hurried bome at nightfall and took refuge from the biting cold of the atmosphere behind thickly drawn curtains and by the side of the largest stove that was ayailable, while those who were fortunate exough to possess a fireplace in their dwelling were regarded with envy by the rest of their lewe fortanate fellows. The cold wave which attacked England in December hes passed and « general thaw has set in, and here again, unless there is a return of extreme cold to the British Isles the predictions of the weather prophets must be admitted to be entirely at fault, for from the early months of the autumn it has been steadily asserted by those who are usually supposed to know, that the winter in England was to be one of more than ordinary severity, every indication having been fegistered to this effect. It may be that the cold which was expected in Eng- land may pass to us, it may be that the world is to be free from any extremes of temperature during the wipter months, and after all, though we may perhaps miss the stimulating influen- ces of the sharper air, we are at least saving oi! and coal bills which ia these days of inflated rentals is at least a blessing not to be desniead

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON. "AIDA."
div.p: "Aida" was really finely given : principals, chorus, orchestra, dancers, all excellent, and the scenery and staging were samptnous, worthy of "Aida's" first and primaeval appearance in Cairo. M. Soubeyran as Rhadames belied his performance as Lobengrin: he was instinct with tone and emphasis ; his lower notes are certainly not pleasing, but in the higher register he can when be is not think- ing of the drawing room tather than the stage—show real power and justify his re putation De Ryk as the king was quite good, and M Coiglio adequate as the high priest, and dignified : his great passage, the sentence of Rhadames—a trap to many a bass —was well given, impressive, and convincing. The chorus was good throughout, and triamph ed over the many difficult momenta where th» singing was behind scenes, and practically unaccompanied : and the orchestra was admirable. The three principal singers M. Valette as Amavasro, Mme Magve as Aida, and Mme Pierens as Amneris, were at their best. M. Va- lette was most excellent, the part suited him, and showed the full extent of bis voice and dramatic power: as usval his was thorough and exact, and, best of all for a baritone, he was never off the note Mme Magne pleases me more and more in every fresh part : she studies and appreciates, her music so thoroughly her scenes with Amneris, aod ber finale with Rbadames conld hardly have been improved for delicacy of intonation : she seems to grasp the exact valoe of every phrase ber mezza-voce notes are a charm. Mme Fierens again showed what a grasp she has of opera, and singing, especially in her denunciation of the bloodthirsty priesthood the eloquence and meaning of her lower notes, and the power and passion of her singing al! through proved how completely she had mastered the part. | certainly have not heard a better version of Aida in Csiro or a better exposition of the possibilities of thie year's compagy. The impression of the music and story Was vivid, it is fine mosic in its way, Victor Hugo on the Ancient East, one would say, pretentious perhaps until the end where appears the 'Ananké,' those mighty Deities, animpressed by the drama of Love and Life and Death passing under their impassive gaze ; they know that they alone can salely play with Death, Love and Life, of which they are the masters, and hamanity their rash, rebellious servants.

I bave omitted certain details which really deserve high praise, the dance of the negroes, weird, selt pleasing, barbaric, and the pageant- triumph of the victorious general, and really fine achievement in grouping and colour unu- sually realistic in that one of the heathen idola tumbled, like Dagon, off his pedestal | . these served to realise the tulness of the opera and to emphasize it asa really notable per- formance.

div.head: AMATEUR THEATRICALS AT CAIRO.
div.p: We are informed that the Ist Battalion 6th Rifles are about to give a dramatic performance at Cairo, in aid of the funds of the Soldiers and Sailors Families Association. The piece selected for presentation is a most amusing farcical.comedy entitled "Our Regiment," the same piece in fact which this Battalion acted with so moch success last winter at Khartoum We onderstand that the Egyptian Govern. ment has most generously placed the Opera Honse at the disposal of the performers, whose stage manager bas already placed himself "en rapport" with the ever courteous impresario, Mons. Poncet. We are confident, therefore, that the piece will have every scenic advantage that it is possible to provide. February 19 is the date selected for the performance

div.head: HOTEL TYANGLETERRE
div.p: Many ne® arrivals have swelled the visitors list at the Hotel d'Angleterre the last day or so, and various otbers are expected before the end of the week. The Countess d'Armandy has arrived and is staying the remainder of the season, and Mr and Mra Acres arrived early on Monday morning. Among other late arrivals are Mr. and Mrs. Tesumann, Mr. and Mrs. H W. Sigg, Mrs. Diem, Mr E Royall Tyler, Mr. J. F Johnson, Dr. Krskin and Mr. Cooper. The list of those expected to arrive to-day are Mr. Weaver with a party of three, Mr. Mason, Mr. and Miss Garrat, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wingate and Mr. Talbot Kelly.

The "Standard" says that it is understood that the British garrison in Egypt will be re duced to 4000, and that the Royal funiskilling Fusiliers and Coldstream Guards will pot be replaced. ( Reuter ) Lowpom; January 14 Nothing is known at the War Office regard. ing the redaction of the garrison ia Egypt. ( Reuter )

div.head: REDUCTION OF GARRISON. . Ee THE HOLTZ MISSION.

div.p: The "Standard" learne from Berlin that the real object of the Holtz mission, which arrived at Jibutil on the 3rd instant, is to obtain con- ceasions to establish an automobile service between Addis Abeba and Dire Dawa, and to seek for orders for arms and ammunition ou behalf of the Bhrhards. The mission has a powerful financial backing. (Reuter) —_—

The Government has decided not to modify ite attitade towards Moroceo but to adhere scrupulously to the Act of Algeciras. (Havas) Panis, January 13 The Chargé d'A ffnires at Tangier telegraphs that there have been no further incidents in the'country. The Ulemas signed the deposition of the Sultan under pressure of the populace The movement signifies an snarchic and not fanatical state. ( Havas) Panis, January 13 The proclamation of Mulay Hafid as Sultan at Per is recognised as a grave event and is causing perturbation here, though some quar ters are disposed to question the importance of the event io view of the constant seesaw of Moroceo politics (Reuter Beatty, January 15 A section of the German press declares that the new situation in Morocco gives Germany s great opportunity and that she should recognise Malay Hafid. ( Reuter) —_—_—_—_—_—

The despatch from the Italian representa tive at Addis Abeba concludes by stating that be had received declarations from the Negu« expressing deep regret and concern. "He con vinced me that he had sothing whatever to du with the raid and that the Ambara chiefs had acted against his express orders." The Italian newspapers consider Meneliks essurances most satisfactory 14th January. Another despatch from the italian representative at Addis Abeba states that the Negus had taken steps to secure the immediate withdrawal of the Abyssinians from Benadir, to organise a search for Captains Bongiovanni and Molinari, and to liberate the prisoners and recover the cattle.

The ice broke at the Bois de Boulogne causing a great panic. Two skaters were killed ( Havas, Paris, January 15 A boy fell through the ice on the lake in the Bois de Boulogne when skaters rushed to hii» help : 30 were immersed and two drowned. ( Reuter )
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught wil! proceed to Egypt at the beginning of February. ( Reuter ) eee)
The State Bank has lowered its rate to 64 (Havas,

Between 50 and 75 persons, mostly women and childreo, were burned or trampled to death and 100 injured owing to a fire due to an explosion in a civematograph exhibition in « theatre at Boyertown (Pennsylvania). (Later). According to the latest information 167 persons are dead and 75 injured The ball was crowded with people to witness a pér- formance given by Sanday school children, and in Sminutes the auditoriom was a furnace.

The Powers have presented a Note to the Porte insisting on prompt assent to the re newal of the mandates of the foreign reform agents in Macedonia The Purte has called out the Redifs and is strengthening the Salonika Army Corps to a full war footing. This is apparently a prepa- ration for anticipated events during the spring or @ demonstration to the Powers of what larkey isable to doin Macedonia (Reuter)
The Senate and the Chamber have opened their session. M. Brisson bas been re-elected President of the Chamber ( Havas)

The Clearing House has voted fot admission to the membership Trust Companies maivtaio- ing a 25% reserve of cash, similar to the National Banks The suspension is announced on the Stock Exchange of the important Robert Maclay Company, the liabilities of which amount to £300,000 ( Reuter ) Wasurwotoy, January 14 The Treasury bas purchased 200,100 ounces silver at 56 747 ( Reuter,

The resumed negotiations in the cotto dispute were broken off yesterday evening, tl parties being unable to agree ( Heuter

As a result of yesterday's demonstrations a hundred arrests bave been made. Thirty per- sons were injured ( Havas) Berioy, Janoary 18. 80 persons were injured during the disor- ders 160 arrests were made yesterday. The Minister of the Interior stated in the Diet that the Government would meet any further disorder with extreme measures. ( Reuter)

Mr. Parman has gained the airship prize of 50,000 frames for covering a closed cirguit of one kilometre. ( Hawes) Penis Janeary 18. « M. Henry Farman has won the Deatech Archdeacon prize of £2,000, having covered with hie agroplane a circular kilometre in 88 seconds. ( Reuter ) Pants, Janoary 14. The Farman aeroplane is 31 feet . long the motor is extremely light : it kept at a height of about 10 feet throughout, and turned and mancuvred with the greatest ease: the weather was most fafourable. ( Reuter )

div.head: EGYPTIAN SITUATION.
div.p: Notwithstanding the financial crisis says the "Financier" of the 4th inst., and ite results, somewhat longer drawn-out than was antici- pated, the general condition of Egypt is one of prosperity and marked progress. The amount of cotton now sentto Alexandria is pat down &* 62,000 cantars more than at this time last year—a cantar is about 100 lbs—and it is stated that some of the cotton is not yet picked, or was not a very few days ago. Respecting the cold consigoments to Egypt, the explanation of the small! (net) aggregate that has been seut this season as compared with last is that the cold already in Egypt has been foond almost nfficient to meet the harvest demands. This is ® most satisfactory condition of affairs It implies two things—that the hoarded and reserved gold in the possession of the fellahs he native merchants and the banks is not on!) n great quantities, but that the hoards are eing teed fora good purpose Enquiries made in well-informed quarter. led to the expreeion of hpefu! opinions as to the immediate future of the country, On gentleman, who has the best opportunities tor geuging the true situation, eapressed his viewas follows — "Egypt is andéwbtedly doing well—ver) well. It is stated, and it is probably true, that some of the cotton is not quite np to the standard that the market expects in Egyptian cotton; bet the prices raling are very good, and either the general quality must be al! right or the demand must be keener thar asuak In either case it will come ont satisfac torily for the fellahs and the merchants as a vhule "Has there been any materia! fall in the value of land owing to the inflation and the risia T" "In building land perhaps there has in certain cases. As to agricaltural land, | ander tand the position is rather peculiar The habits of the people and their notions of bargaining are so different to ours. If an estate, for instance, were suddenly put on the market at a price which, in relation to ite rental. value, might be quite reasonable, it ie quite to be expected there would be no bid for months. Chis would not mean there were not plenty of yossible parchasers at a price close up to that iamed, but that they hoped by delay ito buy cheaper. On the other hand, a man who pos. sesses a good holding will frequently have an offer made for it, which he, acting in « similar way, never actepts promptly. "There was a case | heard of recently where s large estate had been in the market « long time—two or three years, I thuok—and although the amount required for it was ne- turally high, thete was a tedious hegotiation with first'one and then another. The altknate buyer was an Egyptian merchant of grest wealth, who had done his best. to appear quite indiff-rent on the matter At last, | wnder- stand, he was brought to book by learning that * European capitalist was in negotiation A bargain was strook with the merchant, and the transaction was put through at the finish quite quickly, the whole of the purchase money be- ing paid promptly. The apiount was no less than £170,000, aud, instead of a cheque being drawn, on the day agreed upon a little proces sion Of mules drew up at the heuse of the vendor, with bags of goid for the whole som [t transpired that the merchant bad had this money beried under his house, the balk of it being in English sovereigns.

"The rent that is paid for good agricaltural land in the ing, looked at from an English point of view. Twelve pounds « year is not an. uncommon rent, and eight or nine is regasdedvanlam,",.. "The richness of the Nile 'med f suppose, account for it 1". 'Kos, and the certainty of the crops. 'Whiere thane ia peaper, icrigstion, ip. the agri: celtorist can reckon upon a crop every year, end, ofcourse, there is no trouble with the harvest—no thanderstorms, no floods, no frost, no hurricanes." 'Logoats f" A vary remote Flak, an' besclaldg stirs | 80 every year. "What exop ie raised on this land let at £1% a year?" "Cotton, and three orfour others—on the same land, | mean. In fact, where you have irrigation in the Delta you can get several crope in « year off any land "' "Leuppese you agree that the Budget pro- posale afte sound ;" , "Absolotely. If-anything, I should like to gee even more-money spenton the railways. |t is the finest investment the Government can possibly make. Reilways aad irrigation are the two material things that will contribote more than anything else to assure and increase the prosperity, of the qountry. Perhaps the next matter of importance is to wean the people from the hoarding habit. It will natar ally be & slom.paocess, byt the way in which meney has been fortheoming the past antumn is hopeful sign. It. does not fillow that the difference between, this seaaog and last in re gerd to gold consignments is wholly due to the disgarging of the fellabs' hoards. Indeed, it-ae qaite certain, that that ia only a very partial explagation, but at least as regards native merohants it agpears probable that a wember of them—perbaps the younger men who ame not so averse to the adoption of Buropean methods—ere seeing the advantages offered by the banking system, and placing their surplus cash on deposit, The security ofiered by the banks is only pow getting appreciated and believed in. But the exawple of the better-informed patiyes is bound to have ita effect, and | hope in a decade or so the surplus money of the country will no longer lie idle in the way it does now " "What is your opision of the commercia! va lue of the Sudan f" "No living man can appraise the value of the Sudan, but personnally | tijink it basa tremendous future" "What will be the staple prodacts!" "Cotton, maize and, I sapposa, rice, coffee, rubber, and many other tropical crops. And mi nerals may makes great showing eventually, after the country has been thoroughly prospect ed." "Will progress there be as rapid as in Egypt, do you think?" "In a sevse, no doubt, more rapid — on the principle that it is comparatively easy to incre ase a nominal output by a big percentage in a short period; but the growth of any kind of in dastry in the Sudan— and it is all a question uf how much work can be done —depends strict ly upon the labour available, which at present i# limited, and ia, in fact, of comparatively tri Hing extent, particularly when compared with Egypt. Upon'the whole, | should think that the Sudan will achieve steady progress, but that after a certain point the toot difficulty will stand in the way of any rapid advance. Por 'hat, it is an asset of immense value to Eyypt. As time goes on it may turn out that the population of the Delta wil! supply a stream who will find the Sudan an at- tractive Land of Promise." "Could not labour be had from oversea |' "Hardly We hove already sufficient compli cations of races and religions in North-East \fnca, without ipntiodaqing any more But the rate of increase of poplation is, | helieve, very rapid throughout the valley of the Nile. If 'he presperity and enlightenment of the communi ty grow at the same rate there will not be muc!; 0 oumplain of."

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY
div.p: REPORT OF THE COMMISSION. — — A meeting of shareholders of the New Egyptian Company was held at Cairo yesterday afternoon when the following report of the Commission appointed to enquire into the position of the Company was read :-— Messieors, | Votre Commission a l'honneur de vous sou mettre les résultats de |'examen qu'elle vient "de taire de toutes les affaires entreprises direc- tement ou en participation par la New Egyp tian Co. Les chiffres et renseignements qui figurent au présent rapport ont été donnés gracieuse ment, sor la demande de vos Commissaires, par la Direction dela Société, quien conserve toute la responsabilité, sous la réserve qu ils ne sont qu'approximatifs. Terrains Acueres a La Daina Santen. Le Teftiche de Mataana, comprenapt 3457 feddans, dont 4/5 & la Société, a été vendu depuis la oldtare de l'exercice fivissant au 30

suffisamment colmatés pour étre cultivés attei- gnent 1014 feddans, ce qui porte & 2963 fed- dans la superficie totale actuellement culti vable On estime que lorsque tous les colmatages seront achevés, c'est-a dire dans un délaide 8 & 5 ans, suivant |'importance des crues du Nil, la superficie tutale gagnée et achetée atteindra 4819 feddans, ayant cofté 4 cejour environ 170,000 Livres soitun peu plas de 35 Livres par feddan. I] faut observer que toutes les grosses dépenses sont faites et qu'il n'y a plus & prévoir que des d'penses d'entretien des ouvrages et des frais généraux. Le revenu des 2263 feddans actuellement cultivables a été cette année de 11,814 Livres, ce qui porte le loyer moyen du feddan a P. EB. 522 par an et permet d'estimer sa valeur 4 30 Livres Egyptiennes. Plusieurs riverains des terrains gagnés sar le Nil ont revendiqué la propriété de 300 & 400 teddeans colmatés et ont intenté 4 la Société un proces qc elle a perdu en premi re instance. L'affaire est en appel, mais au cas ob le premier jugement serait confirmé, la Société a |'intee tion de réclamer aux gagnants leur quose part dans les d-penses de colmatage. Ejle se base sur ce que les terrains ne pouvajent jamais étre
